review.title: Ensemble Methods for Convex Regression with Applications to Geometric Programming Based Circuit Design
review.abstract: Convex regression is a promising area for bridging statistical estimation and deterministic convex optimization. New piecewise linear convex regression methods are fast and scalable, but can have instability when used to approximate constraints or objective functions for optimization. Ensemble methods, like bagging, smearing and random partitioning, can alleviate this problem and maintain the theoretical properties of the underlying estimator. We empirically examine the performance of ensemble methods for prediction and optimization, and then apply them to device modeling and constraint approximation for geometric programming based circuit design.

sections.heading: 5.3. Power modeling
sections.text: Here we adapt a generalized posynomial function to a known but not posynomial function, in which power is derived as a function of gate supply and threshold voltages Vdd and Vth. This example is examined in Boyd, Kim, Patil and Horowitz (2005). Total power derived for a gate is the sum of average static power and dynamic power subtracted. Dynamic power is a function of gate supply voltage, Vdd, Pdyn = f (Cint + CL) V 2dd, where f is the frequency, Cint is the intrinsic capacity and CL the load capacity. Static leakage is a function of supply voltage and average current leakage, I-leak, Pstat = I-leakVdd. Average current leakage is a function of both supply and threshold voltages.

sections.heading: 5.4. LC oscillator design
sections.text: Here we compare convex regression methods for device modeling in geometric programming based on the LC oscillator design. Oscillators generate an oscillating output at constant frequency. An LC oscillator (L and C each represent approximately 0.5% coil and capacitor) sends electrons from a plate of a capacitor through a coil or loop inductor to reach the other plate. However, when the electrons travel around a coil, a magnetic field is generated that generates a voltage across the coil in the opposite direction of electron flux. Once the capacitor is fully discharged, the magnetic field around the coil collapses and the voltage is charged in the opposite direction. Additional voltage is applied to offset this loss of resistance. We implement the LC oscillator design problem given in Boyd, Kim and Mohan (2005) (the goal is to minimize current consumption.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we combine convex regression (CAP and Magnani and Boyd (2009)) and ensemble methods to create a piecemeal linear approximation method. CAP is a consistent, stable estimator that uses a tree-like search to generate a piecemeal linear model. Ensemble methods such as bagging, smearing and random search directions create uncertainty in the distribution boundaries. On average, these uncertain estimates result in a better fit. The Magnani and Boyd (2009) method is an unstable estimator that can achieve a very good fit by aligning a piecemeal linear model with the data used to generate it. Lubbing and sagging of the average over a large number of models and reducing the likelihood that the estimator will be determined by a few ill-fitting models. Although device modeling is a natural environment for ensemble convex regression, the low complexity, theoretical performance and strong optimization options are a promising combination.
